question:
An email is sent from one email server to another using packet switching.
(a) State two items contained in a packet apart from the data.
mark_scheme: Any two: destination IP address; sender IP address; packet sequence number; checksum.

question:
An email is sent from one email server to another using packet switching.
(b) Explain the role of routers in this transfer.
mark_scheme: A router receives a packet, reads the header (destination address), consults stored data about nearby routers and link usage, and forwards to the next hop; packets to the same destination need not take the same link.

question:
An email is sent from one email server to another using packet switching.
(c) Explain why packet switching is appropriate for email.
mark_scheme: Email tolerates small delays, reordering, and retransmissions; packets can take different routes and be reassembled on arrival.

question:
An email is sent from one email server to another using packet switching.
(d) Name an alternative communication method.

An email is sent from one email server to another using packet switching.
(e) Name an application for which the method in part d) is appropriate and justify.
mark_scheme: Video conferencing or other real-time activity; dedicated route and guaranteed bandwidth with in-sequence delivery avoid delays and reordering issues.

question:
Circuit switching vs packet switching: for each statement, indicate whether it is true or false for each method.
Statements: a dedicated circuit/path is needed at all times; the same route is used for every packet; bandwidth is shared with other packets of data; none of the available bandwidth is wasted during transmission; packets arrive at the destination in the correct order.
mark_scheme:
Circuit switching: True, True, False, False, True.
Packet switching: False, False, True, True, False.

question: Describe how a web page is transferred via packet switching from a web server to a home computer.
mark_scheme: The page is divided into packets; each packet carries the destination address. Routers look up the IP address and, at each hop, decide the next router to reach the destination efficiently; packets may follow different routes and are reassembled by the receiving software.
